div1.head: Report: Summary of Progress Yellow Fever From October 1, 1922 to April 1, 1923
div1.p:
Summary of Progress
Yellow Fever
From October 1, 1922 to April 1, 1923.

From neither pathological nor clinical standpoint has there been
any marked progress in our knowledge of yellow fever during the above in-
terval. For Ssanitation and Eepidemiology the showing is better.

Pathology: Hoffman of Havana (8) states, and shows, that the histo-
pathological lesions in certain organs and tissues (especially the liver
and blood) of guinea pigs infected with Leptospira icteroides (Merida
strain, originally isolated by Noguchi in 1919) are not at all similar to
those produced by yellow fever in man. Grovas-Ferrin of Mexico City (10),
also showing micro-photographs, using a strain from Vera Cruz, finds such
lesions very similar. He suggests that the culture used by Hoffman is con-
taminated.

The writer of Sitjar's paper (12)--it is a translation of one by Borges
Vieyra of São Paula, Brazil--was unable at Nazareth to verify Noguchi's
findings, either bacteriological or immuniological. He frankly admits that
the absence of ice, in a hot climate, and other difficulties incident to
the environment, made a negative result of little significance.

To the writer, the most significant recent determination on this ques-
tion, the etiological role of L. icteroides, is the frequent positive im-
muniological reaction given by the blood of men recently recovered from
yellow fever with L. icteroides. That with L. ictero-haemorrhagicahas
been negative. If this reaction is shown to be universal, or even ex-
tremely general, it will be (a) evidence of value on this question and (b)
a laboratory method of diagnosis of the disease recovered from fairly prac-
ticable under field conditions--an inestimable boon to sanitarians.

Clinically. Nothing new has been added which we can accept.
The figures given by Anigstein (1) on the case mortality of yellow fever,
whites 94%: Blacks 64%, would, indeed, mark a new departure from the teach-
ings of any modern clinician; but they are much too high, as the rate given
by Carter (2)--7%--as occurring in Payta, 1920, is too low for the usual
average. The case mortality in hospital among the “Gold Roll” employees,
Americans, British, French etc. on the Canal Zone in 1905 was 26.3% and
this was a decidedly severe type of fever: the patients were all newly ar-
rived from colder countries and adults, among whom the mortality is decid-
edly greater than among the general population with a reasonable number of
children. That the fever was mainly among people under twenty--the older
people being immune from a previous epidemic about 18 years before--was
one of the factors in the low mortality at Payta. The normal mortality
among blacks is extremely small.

Sanitation. Much detail valuable to the sanitarian engaged in a cam-
paign against yellow fever in an endemic focus, is given by the field-work-
ers in Mexico. Connor's papers (3): (4): & (5) are well worth reading to this
end. Rightly he stresses fish-control wherever practicable, as do Carter (2)
and Hanson in his Peruvian Campaign of 1921-22 (report not published) to the
success of which it was the key. After trying many kinds all give the pre-
ference to bottom-feeding minnows: in in Mexico the Mojarra (Aequidens rivu-
latus (G) of the Cichlidae)--a small perch: in Peru the Life (Phygidium punctu-
latum puiral (Eigenmenn), looking like a little cat-fish. (Foot note)

This latter, indeed, feeds at the surface at night. Both are hardy--Life
extremely so--and neither are apt to jump out of the container. Naturally,
bottom feeders are not liable (a) to be injured by sudden changes of tem-
perature, as during Northers in Mexico, or (b) to be washed out when the
cisterns overflow--to both of which accidents top-feeders, the fish first
used, are subject. Scannell (personal communication) has found Mojarra to
to do well in deep (30 ft. or more) wells and that it was the only fish
that he could depend on in such places.

Houle, of Empalme, Sonora, Mexico (unpublished report) has used a
predatory aquatic insect, “water boatmen” (Notanecta, spec.)--also a bot-
tom feeder--to advantage (a) in collections of water too small for fish
(the west coast of Mexico is dry and water scarce) and (b) in the ashes-
water of the laundresses, in which no fish will live, but which produces
aegypti in profusion. The editor, however, regards the use of this in-
sect as very limited, though useful in those limits. The control of breed-
ing in this agua ceniza has been an important and a difficult problem in

Mexico and Central America. This water is too valuable to be thrown away--
to do so would lead to hiding it--it cannot be oiled and fish will not live
in it. We controlled it satisfactorily in Peru by the addition of soap,
which was not objected to, and this will be tried in Mexico.

Epidemiology. With this the papers of Peterson (11) and Dunn (6):
most of Carter's (2) and much of Connor's (3: 4: and 5) are concerned. The
points specially brought out are: (11) the spontaneous elimination of yellow
fever from the Virgin Islands (St. Thomas especially used to be virulently
infected) by the "failure of the human host--aegypti being extremely abun-
dant there. In this connection Connor, in a personal communication, ex-
presses the, tentative, opinion that yellow fever had been eliminated from
Merida--by failure of the human host--before sanitary (mosquito control)
work was undertaken, the extensive epidemics just previous thereto having
exhausted the susceptible himan material. One can see how a marked in-
crease of infection in a community receiving few immigrants might have
the effect of thus leading to its own extinction! Connor (E) also notes
the concentration and permanence of infection in endemic canters about
hotels and the boarding houses of strangers.

We may note here too the formulation by Carter (Unpublishec Lectures,
Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene), as the result of many observations: in
various countries: for a number of years; of the obligatory limits (nega-
tive) for aegypti breeding. “The eggs of this species have not been found
to have been deposited by the imago in any collection of water the sides
of which at the water line consist entirely of mud.” The editor is of the opinion
that this limitation is not only generally but universally true and that
a knowledgethe acceptance of it will, to an extent, simplify sanitary measures.

Historical and Geographical. The abstract of Gouzien's paper (7)
is so full that no comment is needed. It is only necessary to say that
that

after a period of over two and a half years, Sept. 11/19 to June 12/22,
during which no yellow fever was reported from Africa it has again appear-
ed there, scattered from the Gambia to the mouth of the Niger and over
600 miles inland (on the Niger). Recent advices show it increasing.

In March a report was received, which was later verified, of an epi-
demic of yellow fever at Bucaramanga, Colombia, a town slightly over 3,000 ft.
above sea-level. No infection had been reported from this regional focus--
in the South Caribbean--since 1917 (at Coro, Venezuela, by Guiteras) and
there was reason to hope that, with the lessened travel due to the Great
War, this section had been freed from infection spontaneously. It will
probably, this region now being decidedly prosperous with much travel in
it, require much sanitary work--control of aegypti production--to eliminate
it. Without this it will likely last indefinitely and extend.
